text: second reactor out of three active
reactors at the troubled Japanese
nuclear power plant is now venting
considerable quantities of radioactive
steam after what authorities described
as a possible rupture the reactor does
not appear to be on fire it's not
producing the enormous quantities of
radioactive material that we saw coming
out of the Chernobyl plant a quarter
century ago but it is serious concern
for the authorities among other problems
increased radiation from steam coming
out of troubled reactors it makes it a
lot harder to clean up or at least may
even manage the other reactors it also
makes it harder for workers to keep cool
they spent uranium fuel rods that have
been kept for years in large pools of
water on top of the reactors the water
in those spent fuel rod ponds has been
boiling away and that has been a big
concern for the authorities because of
the increase in radiation the government
and Tokyo Electric the electric utility
that owns this power plant have at least
for now put on hold their plans to try
to use helicopters to dump water on top
of troubled reactors and de spent fuel
rod storage pools the helicopters would
be exposed to a lot of radiation if they
were to be up there now Tokyo Electric
had before this latest puff of steam
coming up from reactor 3 been increasing
somewhat the number of people working
inside the plant to try to manage the
situation they had gone up from 50
workers to a hundred some of them have
apparently now had to take shelter
because of the additional release of
radioactivity
